Db​a​c​k​d​o​o​rsubscript𝐷𝑏𝑎𝑐𝑘𝑑𝑜𝑜𝑟D_{backdoor} backdoor data (used in Algorithm 2)
references:
Participant-level differential privacy. 
Differentially private federated learning (fedlearn_dp, ; geyer2017differentially, ) bounds each participant’s influence over
the joint model. In Section 6.3, we evaluate the
extent to which it mitigates our attacks. PATE (pate, ; pate2, ) uses
knowledge distillation (hinton2015distilling, ) to transfer knowledge
from “teacher” models trained on private data to a “student” model.
Participants must agree on the class labels that may not exist in their
own datasets, thus PATE may not be suitable for tasks like next-word
prediction with a 50K dictionary (fedlearn_dp, ). The purpose of
federated learning is to train on private data that are distributed
differently from the public data. It is not clear how knowledge
transfer works in the absence of unlabeled public data drawn from the
same distribution as the teachers’ private data.

With continuous training (nguyen2017variational, ; catastrophic2017, ),
converged models are updated by participants throughout their deployment.
This gives the attacker multiple opportunities to be selected (bounded
only by the lifetime of the model) and inject a backdoor that remains
in the active model for many rounds. Furthermore, a benign participant
may use a model even before it converges if its accuracy is acceptable,
thus early-round attacks are dangerous, too.

Table 1 shows the norm of the update needed to achieve high
backdoor accuracy after we replace is and delicious
in the backdoor with more or less popular words. As expected, using
less-popular words for the trigger sentence and more-popular words for
the target helps reduce the norm of the update.

Estimating SSS. 
The anomaly detector may conceal from the participants the norm bound S𝑆S
that it uses to detect “anomalous” contributions. The attacker has two
ways to estimate the value of S𝑆S: (1) sacrifice one of the compromised
participants by iteratively increasing S𝑆S and submitting model updates
using Eq. 5 until the participant is banned, or
(2) estimate the distribution of weight norms among the benign
participants by training multiple local models either on random inputs,
or, in the case of word-prediction models, on relatively hard inputs
(see Table 1). Because the anomaly detector cannot afford
to filter out most benign contributions, the attacker can assume that S𝑆S
is set near the upper bound of this distribution.

The first method requires multiple compromised participants but
no domain knowledge. The second method requires domain knowledge
but yields a good local estimate of S𝑆S without triggering the
anomaly detector. For example, the mean of norms for word-prediction
models trained on popular words as input and rare words as output (per
Table 1) cuts out only the top 5% of the benign updates.
The two estimation methods can also be used in tandem.

the joint model. In Section 6.3, we evaluate the
extent to which it mitigates our attacks. PATE (pate, ; pate2, ) uses

Participants must agree on the class labels that may not exist in their

With continuous training (nguyen2017variational, ; catastrophic2017, ),

The anomaly detector may conceal from the participants the norm bound S𝑆S
that it uses to detect “anomalous” contributions. The attacker has two

is set near the upper bound of this distribution.

The first method requires multiple compromised participants but

but yields a good local estimate of S𝑆S without triggering the

The two estimation methods can also be used in tandem.
